poem:
A Drift in Parliament's Light  

Macron whispers in the Royal Gallery—  
Brexit, a distant hum  
in the tapestry of history.  
Words weave, pause, shift—  
a French nod, a coded sigh.  
Across old, polished wood,  
an echo of choices,  
a pause in time.  
The gallery heeds,  
a silent ripple beneath  
the brusque leaves of autumn.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Five key takeaways from Macron’s speech to UK parliament Emmanuel Macron, making the state visit by a European head of state to the UK since Brexit, has addressed MPs and peers in the Royal Gallery in parliament. Here are five standout moments from his speech A mild dig at Brexit Nine years on from the referendum, and coded laments about Brexit are more palatable. The French president said that while the UK was no longer". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
